text: Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller? Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, a biologic, so not a chemo. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many, many arms of this trial. It’s like the octopus study. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where there’s a lot. But you’re basically taking a pill. There is a pathway that’s always screwed up with prostate cancer. This sort of tackles that pathway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness.

text: Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors. Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in the past you know we talked about the backup plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, We checked, you know, the one, the new therapy setting still where you live at. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Some of it is sometimes that blood test that’s fluctuating could be better. Doctor: Because if you’re seven and remained positive, then you’re eligible for one study versus another study. Patient: Oh.

text: Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? And you have the desire, uh, but there may be a point where I think you maybe too sick or your labs don’t work, or there are other things that suggest that more therapy is not the right thing. Patient: I see. Doctor: I will say that to you. It may not be what you want to hear. Patient: It’s the reality. (Pause) Doctor: As long as the quality’s good. That’s my worry. Okay? You can get extra time, but if it sucks, then it’s (not awful) Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
